Thank you Gordon.

We do not plan to do repeated crawls, but capture a 1 billion page 
dataset to be used for information retrieval research purposes.  We 
would like to capture as many high quality pages as possible.

We would also like to have a blacklist of unwanted sites.  This 
blacklist would possibly contain millions hosts.  Do you have any 
experience in the resources needed for this?  Would this slow down the 
speed of the crawl?

In our small crawls that we have been running, we found that although we 
have setup for a breadth first crawl, days into the crawl and 10's of 
million of pages crawled, the crawler has still only crawled a small 
percentage of seeds (under 10% of a 2 million host seed list - 1200 
threads).  It appears that most of the seeds are in a separate queue so 
would cycling through the queues (balance-replenish-amount to a lower 
amount maybe 100) help cover all of the queues?

--David

On 11/7/2011 2:44 PM, Gordon Mohr wrote:
> Heritrix is not very accommodating for an OPIC-ordered crawl in the way
> that it is not easy to reorder URIs inside a single queue, once they are
> queued. (You'd have to peel them all off, sort, and re-queue... which
> might offset some or all of whatever ordering benefit you were hoping to
> achieve.)
>
> You can, however, re-prioritize entire queues via the queue-precedence
> mechanism. So you could bias the crawler to spend more early effort on
> sites that are large, or have a larger number of total inlinks, or other
> measures.
>
> If you are performing repeated crawls, you could also use PR
> calculations from a completed earlier crawl to bias the ordering of a
> later crawl (because you would have PR values usable at the moment of
> queueing).
>
>  From a quick glance at the paper you reference, it doesn't seem like
> the magnitude of benefit for incremental-PR-estimation is very large. As
> they attribute to their footnote [11], and other broad-crawl studies
> have also suggested, "even a random strategy can perform well on the
> Web, in the sense that a random walk on the Web is biased towards pages
> with high Pagerank". For this reason, I wouldn't be too concerned about
> crawling in PR-order unless you know you often have to cut your crawl
> short and thus strongly suspect more important pages are not being
> crawled... and even in that case, in a repeated crawl series you could
> adjust future crawls to offset this problem.
>
> Also important to note: a strict 'breadth-first' crawl isn't a realistic
> description of any large politeness-limited crawl. Almost immediately in
> any crawl, politeness-to-servers means you may only be a few hops deep
> into big sites, while being arbitrarily deep on other paths that are
> spread over many non-politeness-bottlenecked servers. This certainly
> helps in discovering (and crawling to completeness) new and
> small-URI-count independent servers... though it leaves the risk that
> potentially 'important' (by PR) pages, 'deep' within large servers, may
> not be reached within some capped time/storage budget.
>
> - Gordon
>
